newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES EDGE HIGHER ON THURSDAY.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES EDGE HIGHER ON THURSDAY.

text.p: Short-term trading rates on Zimbabwe's money market hardened further on Thursday in a market made short by a central bank bill auction, dealers said.
"The Reserve Bank offered Z$200 million worth of treasury bills to the market and it's now short," one dealer said.

He said all the bills were taken up at a 22.44 percent yield, up from 20.99 percent at the last auction on Tuesday, adding that other rates were also being quoted firmer in sympathy, though there was not much active traded.
Discount houses were indicating to sell treasury bills at 22 percent on the secondary market from Wednesday's 20.5 percent, while call money edged up two percentage points to 20 percent.
NCD bills redeemable after 30, 60 and 90 days were being bought at 23 percent from 22 and sold firmer at 22.5 percent compared to 21.5 percent.

Bankers acceptances were at 22.25 and 22 percent (buying and selling respectively) from 20.75 and 20.25 percent, in a market which opened with a slight surplus of Z$34.9 million from a previous Z$32.7 million shortage.
